comment_0: I know this may sound a little dumb, but I always liked to think of this song being sung in the perspective of the man in prison telling the others he shares a cell with why he's in there in the first place, with the Whiskey being an actual bottle of Whiskey that is being passed around by the prisoners.
comment_1:
Just as a point of interest, these are the original lyrics as my grandmother used to sing them....

As I was going over the far famed Kerry mountains
I met with captain Farrell and his money he was counting. 
I first produced my pistol, and then produced my rapier.
Said stand and deliver, for I am a bold deceiver,

musha ring dumma do damma da 
whack for the daddy 'ol
whack for the daddy 'ol
there's whiskey in the jar

I counted out his money, and it made a pretty penny.
I put it in my pocket and I took it home to Jenny.
She said and she swore, that she never would deceive me,
but the devil take the women, for they never can be easy

I went into my chamber, all for to take a slumber,
I dreamt of gold and jewels and for sure it was no wonder.
But Jenny took my charges and she filled them up with water,
Then sent for captain Farrel to be ready for the slaughter.

musha ring dumma do damma da 
whack for the daddy 'ol
whack for the daddy 'ol
there's whiskey in the jar


It was early in the morning, as I rose up for travel,
The guards were all around me and likewise captain Farrel.
I first produced my pistol, for she stole away my rapier,
But I couldn't shoot the water so a prisoner I was taken.

If anyone can aid me, it's my brother in the army,
If I can find his station down in Cork or in Killarney.
And if he'll come and save me, we'll go roving near Kilkenny,
And I swear he'll treat me better than me darling sportling Jenny

Now some men take delight in the drinking and the roving,
But others take delight in the gambling and the smoking.
But I take delight in the juice of the barley,
And courting pretty fair maids in the morning bright and early

musha ring dumma do damma da 
whack for the daddy 'ol
whack for the daddy 'ol
there's whiskey in the jar

comment_29: Thin Lizzy's version is good, just different. i like them both. "The Whiskey In The Jar" part is an allusion to women. at the time this song was originally written, 'jar' was a common metaphor for the female genitalia, as well as being a container in which whiskey was kept. so in a allegorical way, he is saying that being in love is like being drunk. whiskey jars and the female genitalia both have in them things that will fuck you up, basically. so basically the song is about the evils of women and drink and how you`ll end up fucked by both of them.

This song has changed over time.  It originated as a folk song and then Thin Lizzy recorded it.  Metallica was influenced by Lizzy and they did this as a cover.

It's the story of a thief who steals stuff for his girl and fights lots but then gets sent to jail.

Great song, better band.

comment_54:
Maybe this will help everyone, I love metal, but being Irish I love Irish Folk songs too, Here I will list all the differences between the Metallica and Folk versions

Metallica: "...Cork and Kerry Mountains...
Folk: "...Far Famed Kerry Mountains

Metallica: "...or the devil he may take ya..."
Folk: "...For ye were a bold deciever..."

Metallica: 
"I took all of his money and it was a pretty penny"
Folk: 
"I counted out his money and it made a pretty penny"

Metallica:
"I took all of his money yeah I took it home to Molly"
Folk: I put it in me pocket and I took it home to Jenny"

Metallica: 
"She swore that she'd love me, never would she leave me"
Folk: "She sidled and she swore that she never would decieve me"

Metallica: 
"But the devil take that woman for you know she treat me easy"
Folk: 
"But the devil take the women for they never can be easy"

Metallica: "Whack for the daddy-o"
Folk: "Whack Fol-de-dol-de-o"

Metallica:
"Being drunk and weary I went to Molly's chamber 
Takin' my money with me and I never knew the danger 
For about six or maybe seven in walked Captain Farrell 
I jumped up, fired off my pistols and I shot him with both barrels"
Folk: 
"I went into my chamber all for to take a slumber
I dreamt of gold and jewels and for sure it was no wonder
That Jenny drew me charges and she filled 'em up with water
Then sent for Captain Farrell to be ready for the slaughter"

Metallica:-Nothing-
Folk:
" 'Twas early in the morning just before I rose to travel
Up comes a band of thug men and likewise Captain Farrell
I first produced me pistol for she'd stolen away me rapier 
but I couldn't shoot the water so a prisoner I was taken"

Metallica:
"Now some men like the fishin' and some men like the fowlin' 
And some men like ta hear, ta hear cannon ball a roarin' 
Me I like sleepin' specially in my Molly's chamber 
But here I am in prison, here I am with a ball and chain yeah" 
Folk: "Now there's some take delight in the carriages a rollin'
and others take delight in the harley and the bowling
but I take delight in the juice of the barley
and courting pretty fair maids in the morning bright and early"

Metallica: -Nothing-
Folk: "If anyone can aid me, tis me brother in the army
If I can find his station in Cork or in Killarney
and if he'll go with we'll go rovin' in Killkenney
and I'm sure he'll treat me better than me only sporting Jenny"

Maybe these difference will help you decipher the true meaning of this song. Hope I helped.

comment_93:
James voice recordings early on were shit.  The voice recordings from songs like this were good.  If the recordings were better back in the 80s, then Metallica would be better than they already are; if anything, only slightly.  Hetfield's a good singer, though, the early productions didn't bring it out.

Ya, Thin Lizzy cover.  They covered an Irish folk tune because they're, well, Irish >>  I find this better, possibly due to the heavier riffs and I like Metallica better than Lizzy.  Mind, Lizzy are the masters of acoustic/electric combination, but I like the power chords better >>  They're different styles; they made this song Heavy Metal where Thin Lizzy were Hard Rock.

I do agree, Hetfield's voice lacked the emotion Phil Lynnot's had.

comment_101:
This is one of my favorite songs. Heard Metallica's first but I like all versions... also, I have an x named Molly who crushed me pretty good and so I wanted to know if âMollyâs chambersâ meant anything, especially when I heard it in a kings of leon song.  âMollyâs chambers gonna change your mindâ¦â  Anyway, I looked into what these lyrics might be all about and hereâs what I found take it or leave it...  Itâs a long one, I know but some of this fits together pretty wellâ¦

as has been mentioned already by many, this is originally an old irish drinking song about a man who robs captain farrell, brings the money home to his girl, then gets betrayed by her and taken to jail. (he then breaks out and the last verse is about wanting to find his brother who will treat him more honestly than his girl did)... in that song though, its Jenny, not Molly. I admit that the name may have been interchangeable since lyrics of drinking songs are often changed by drunks like myself but at least in every version Iâve seen of the original so far itâs âJennyâ. Obviously, thatâs interesting to me since I was curious about the mollyâs chamber part of the lyrics. It made me ask myself, why would Thin Lizzy who I think did the first rock cover have changed the name to Molly and the verse to Mollyâs chambers (instead of my chambers or jennyâs chambers)?  I started thinking that it might have something to do with the title being about alcohol or just being Fed up. An important point, I donât think you can rule the fact that this song has something to do with booze out completely even if it is an old story song. If you know anything about drinking a lot, loving a girl and feeling betrayed, youâll know thereâs a pretty strong connection there, especially if youre a bit of a scoundrel yourself. So even in the original, I think the song is so good because its about all that stuffâ¦ anyway, I found the phrase in one other place - the book, âSilas Marnerâ by George Eliot (actually a woman) and hereâs the excerpt: 

âJust and self-reproving thoughts do not come to us too thickly, even in the purest air, and with the best lessons of heaven and earth; how should those white-winged delicate messengers make their way to Molly's poisoned chamber, inhabited by no higher memories than those of a barmaid's paradise of pink ribbons and gentlemen's jokes?â 

Fits pretty well. One message I see is: âWhen youâve done wrong yourself and then wrong happens to you, itâs tough to see that you brought it on yourself.â And thereâs also the fact that the character in this book is hooked on opium and has a had filled with âno higher memories than those of a barmaidâsâ Iâm wondering if âMollyâs Chamberâ came to mean anything after this phrase and if it was a term âthin lizzyâ  had in mind when rewriting the song. 

Or maybe George Eliot was making a reference to this old songâ¦ or maybe itâs a total coincidenceâ¦ but even if either of those is true and the use of the word molly is just random or a result of there being an alternate original version that uses molly instead of jenny â this song is definitely about cheating, loving, drinking, being cheated yourself by a woman and being sad, which I think its safe to assume leads to more drinkingâ¦ just because itâs a folk song doesnât mean thereâs no deeper meaning to it. 

One more note: The Kings of Leon song (if you donât know the band, you may remember the car commercial with the song in it) sticks to the original version of the story where the girl takes the guys gun powder out of his pistol and fills the charges with water. The lyric in that song is âSheâs gotâ¦ your pistol.â Check out the song and the band for that matter, their first two albums are damn good.

comment_103:
Ok this is NOT the correct interpretation of the song, but when I first heard it, it meant this to me:

Some (poor) guy is kicked out of the army (possibly for drunkeness), his "boss" or captain, was of course, "Captain Farrell". As he is heading back home to the only good thing in his life (his girlfriend Jenny/Molly) he sees "Captain Farrell", and knowing that his girlfriend will be pissed off when he comes home drunk, sacked and penniless, robs the fucker. When he brings the money home, she tells him she love him and she' never leave him. They have sex and he finds "Whiskey in the jar", if you know what i mean (basically, Jenny/Molly has been cheating on him with none other than Captain Farrel), when Captain Farrel shows up at Molly's chamber, he kills him, and is put in jail.

It just shows that no matter how much you love someone, no matter how hard you try to look after them or make them happy, if you don't have money there will always be some rich fucker trying to take what little you have away from you. The narrator of this song is an example to self-made men everywhere, don't let anyone fuck you about, stand up for yourself, look after you family and your friends and especially your girls, and if anyone tries to interfere, fuck them up.

comment_117: in the original song, Captain Ferrell is somewhat a bit of a seedy character.  That doesn't come out in this version unfortunately.  Molly was originally Jenny too.  And in the original, the main character believes that his brother will come bail him out of prison.  This version is alright, but certainly not the best, there's a great one by The Oddsods.  This song wasn't meant to be a downer, it actually was quite a fast paced song to teach a lesson about drinking and stealing (but people usually drank along while listening to it).  The Grateful Dead created a version of this that Thin Lizzy reworked.  If you look on Project Playlist you can find a whole bunch of Whiskey in the Jar versions.

comment_123:
Ok, for your consideration, Thin Lizzy changed the lyrics in a perfect way to tell their version. This is what I believe they were thinking (Not necessarily the old Irish Meaning).

Hero (for lack of a better description) is a Pirate. Captain Farrell is a Pirate Captain. They make land after a Successful Pirate Raid and Hero seeks out finds Captain Farrell and "produces his (1) Pistol and then his Rapier (Sword)" (important point later). He takes the loot to his Molly and wants her to run off with him (he can't stick around, Captain Farrell will catch him if he does).

"Mush a Ring Dam a do dam a da" is Molly stammering trying to think of how to deal with the situation, because, although she loves it when he comes off his raids with a dollar or two, she's not going anywhere with him. She gets the idea to stall the Hero until Captain Farrell can get there, by saying she doesn't want to leave without first saying goodbye to her Father:

Molly says:

"Wait for my Daddy. Oh, there's whisky in the jar." 
He grabs the jar of whiskey and Molly and starts for Molly's chamber and Molly says "Oh". 
"Wait for my Daddy, Oh, There's Whiskey in the Jar, Oh"

When Captain Farrell enters Mollyâs Chamber the song goes "I jumped OFF, fired off my pistols and I shot him with BOTH barrels". Remember eariler he produced his Pistol and then his Rapier. He only had one Pistol. The second pistol was his Cock, which Molly had been holding onto to prevent him from finishing the deed before Captain Farrell can get there. In support of this interpretation, the last trailing/fading out lines are âI loved, I loved, I loved my Molly and she was holding my barrel. That dirty child that dirty, dirty, dirty childâ.

I believe his prison is not a real prison but a reference to Molly leaving with him, now that Farrell is dead and stained.

I love this song by Thin Lizzy. Metalica is a little hard for my tastes, but am very glad that the next generation put their Stamp on it!

Iâm just saying!
comment_124:
This is not just a simple tune nor is it merely a "bunch a rhymin' words".
Irish songs are Irish stories.
Irishmen are proud story tellers..,they are the"Bards" of whom Shakespeare wrote in his plays.
From town to town the news of the land was spread by the tales told by these 'Bards'and then ...,
then it found itself being repeated again and again,until it took on a rythm and melody of its' own.
Thus a song was born that would keep alive the tale.
"Whiskey in the Jar" may seem a whimsical title at first glance.
Hear the words and recognize them for the time from whence they came and you instead will find a dark novel playing out before you.
   The highwaymen were Irishmen who fought against the tyranny being imposed by the occupying British Empire.
   They were the "Robin-hoods of Eire" .
 { Picture this--there are some who could say that we[the Irish] were the last gasp at the British attempt of maintaining some sort of slave/servant cast.}
  Ireland needed Heroes.
  When these songs are played now---I WILL TELL YOU THIS--IT IS RIDICULOUS AND DEMEANING TO THE SONG TO HEAR ANYONE SAY IT IS NOT BEING PLAYED CORRECTLY.
   THE MOST IMPORTANT THING IS THAT THE SONG IS PLAYED,THE SONG IS SUNG,AND THE GETS TOLD AND IS NEVER FORGOTTEN.
   Seems simple to me ehh?
     "9/11 Gone but not forgotten"
comment_125:
Firstly: "Whack" was a British sailor term (and later, for sailors everywhere) for the "daily ration," that was specified by law. It was a very specific minimum standard for both food and water, even salt. It became slang for all folks of that time, and everyone knew what it meant. So "Whack for my daddio," means something like "this is all I need," the "whiskey in the jar."

No luck deciphering the "musha ring ...," so far.
